Term.Name: Proprietary
Term.Definition: For use where proprietary extensions are required, or the use of keywords that do not fit in any classification below

Term.Name: Daily news
Term.Definition: regular programme carrying breaking and current news stories e.g. News at ..

Term.Name: Special news/edition
Term.Definition: one off programme to carry specific news events e.g. coverage of breaking news such as train crash

Term.Name: Special Report
Term.Definition: one off programme to carry specific news worthy events e.g.exclusive report on specific item

Term.Name: Periodical/General
Term.Definition: regular timely programme covering general newsworthy items

Term.Name: National politics/National assembly
Term.Definition: new coverage of political events eg parliamentary coverage

Term.Name: Economy/Market/Financial/Business
Term.Definition: e.g. financial news programme from stock market

Term.Name: Sports
Term.Definition: news of sporting events NB not to be used for regular sporting coverage

Term.Name: Cultural
Term.Definition: news of cultural significance. NB only to be used when coverage is newsworthy. Oterwise use 3.1.4 or 3.1.10

Term.Name: Osho
Term.Definition: Formerly known as Bhagwan Shree Rajneesh

Term.Name: The Creativity Movement
Term.Definition: Formerly called World Church of the Creator

Term.Name: Activities
Term.Definition: Activities, particularly children's activities, which may or may not be educational.

Term.Name: Music
Term.Definition: Programme about a musical subject: NB if the content is predominantly the music itself this is not the category to be used - instead refer to 3.6 Music e.g. biography of Mozart not a relay of a concert of his music

Term.Name: Theatre
Term.Definition: Programme about the theatre such as a review programme: not a programme consisting of the play itself

Term.Name: Cinema
Term.Definition: Programme about subject concerning the world of the film and cinema not the film itself

Term.Name: Plastic arts
Term.Definition: Includes sculpture, carving, pottery and weaving

Term.Name: Humanities
Term.Definition: The branches of learning regarded as having primarily a cultural character and which usually include language, literature, history, mathematics and philosophy

Term.Name: Applied sciences
Term.Definition: Sciences dealing with material phenomena or industrial processes

Term.Name: Medicine
Term.Definition: Programmes about medical subjects, health etc

Term.Name: Reality
Term.Definition: Programme based on real life, usually by the camera observing without changing what is happening ("fly on the wall documentary" for example)

Term.Name: Air
Term.Definition: Programme consisting of elements on aviation as means of commercial aviation. Elements concerning private pilots and general aviation should go in leisure/Hobbies, aviation (3.3.34) Programme consisting of elements on aviation as sport should go in (3.2.14)

Term.Name: Events
Term.Definition: Coverage of events, not the event itself (see format)

Term.Name: Listings
Term.Definition: information about schedules to be broadcast

Term.Name: Shinty
Term.Definition: Scottish game, also known as Camanachd.

Term.Name: Auto racing
Term.Definition: Motor car racing not covered elsewhere - eg Formula Ford, Formula .000, V8 championship etc

Term.Name: Trotting
Term.Definition: Horse with two wheel cart and a jockey

Term.Name: Air sports
Term.Definition: Programme consisting of elements on aviation as sport. Elements concerning commercial aviation should be categorized in Air Transport (3.1.8.1) and elements concerning private pilots and general aviation should go in Leisure/Hobbies, aviation (3.3.34)

Term.Name: Mind Games
Term.Definition: Competetive tests of mental acuity. This category should only be used where the coverage relates to the competetivemness of the event. It is not intended for use where the coverage is intended for education purposes

Term.Name: Traditional Games
Term.Definition: Intended for local use for specific traditional national games

Term.Name: FICTION/DRAMA
Term.Definition: Programme consisting of a prose or verse composition, resp. one telling a story, written for or as if for performance by actors, puppets or animated

Term.Name: General light drama
Term.Definition: Drama written after approximately 1918 and without literary or cultural pretensions. Popular drama, e.g. Upstairs, Downstairs

Term.Name: Soap
Term.Definition: Dramatized serial programme dealing with easy-to-grasp situations performed by a limited cast

Term.Name: Legal Melodrama
Term.Definition: Drama production where the primary action takes place in law courts and/or law firms e.g. Philadelphia

Term.Name: Medical melodrama
Term.Definition: Drama production situated in hospitals and/or dealing with medical subjects e.g. ER, Dr kildaire, Casualty

Term.Name: Epic
Term.Definition: Dramatized narrative about the deeds of a traditional or historical hero or heroes and/or dealing with or characterized by events of historical or legendary importance e.g. El Cid

Term.Name: Drama based on real events (docudrama)
Term.Definition: Drama based upon reality sometimes with documentary inserts

Term.Name: Classical drama
Term.Definition: Drama written before approximately 1918 e.g. Hamlet, Othello

Term.Name: Period drama
Term.Definition: Drama depicting events before 1918 e.g. Pride and Prejudice

Term.Name: Contemporary drama
Term.Definition: Drama written after approximately 1918 and with literary and/or cultural value e.g. Waiting for Godot

Term.Name: Political Drama
Term.Definition: Telling a story or recounting events in which the main characters are politicians or where the main action takes place in political institutions.

Term.Name: Quiz/Contest
Term.Definition: Competitions calling into play the competitors' special knowledge and intelligence

Term.Name: Quiz
Term.Definition: Who Wants to be a millionaire - questions and answers form the entertainment

Term.Name: Contest
Term.Definition: Participants compete directly with each other eg Americas Top Model, Generation Game

Term.Name: Variety/Talent
Term.Definition: Programme with various performers such as comedians, magicians, singers etc. e.g. Paul Daniels Show, Relay from a circus

Term.Name: Cabaret
Term.Definition: Specific instance of Variety in an intimate environment

Term.Name: Talent
Term.Definition: Spelling Bees, singing talent shows - Stars in their eyes, American Idol

Term.Name: Surprise
Term.Definition: Programme of 'dream comes true' type e.g. Jim'llFix It

Term.Name: Broken comedy
Term.Definition: Humorous and/or satirical programme consisting of short dramatical sequences, sketches, performed by comedians e,g, Benny Hill, Monty Python

Term.Name: Sitcom
Term.Definition: Dramatized series in a humorous style and performed by a more or less fixed cast e.g. Friends, The Office

Term.Name: Candid Camera
Term.Definition: Programme in which the recording device is hidden so the participants are not aware they are being recorded.

Term.Name: Humour
Term.Definition: Programme without sketches or “broken drama”, consisting (mainly) of verbal jokes, gags, bloopers etc.

Term.Name: Spoof
Term.Definition: Imitating other works in order to ridicule or derive humour from the work itself and its subject matter.

Term.Name: Chat
Term.Definition: Chat Show in which a presenter interviews a celebrity

Term.Name: Classical music
Term.Definition: Music including chamber, instrumental, operatic, symphonic, vocal and choral music

Term.Name: Early
Term.Definition: Music written before the middle of the 17th Century

Term.Name: Classical
Term.Definition: Music from the middle of the 18th until the end of the 19th Century

Term.Name: Jazz
Term.Definition: Indigenous American popular music, born in New Orleans of African slaves social circumstances. The jazz idiom is characterized by certain syncopations over strongly reiterated rhythms in which improvisation plays an important part

Term.Name: Bop/Hard bop/Bebop/Postbop
Term.Definition: e.g. Sonny Rollings, Oscar Peterson, J. Coltrane, T. Monk

Term.Name: Middle-of-the-road
Term.Definition: Music which, in varying circumstances, gives pleasure to the widest possible spectrum of the music-loving audience

Term.Name: Pop-rock
Term.Definition: The most central and widely circulated types of popular music, in particular rock and roll, etc

Term.Name: Classic/Dance/Pop-rock
Term.Definition: e.g. Michael Jackson, Spice Girls, Johnny Halliday, Rolling Stones

Term.Name: R and B
Term.Definition: 1990s RandB (e.g. Teddy Riley) not 1960s Rhythm and Blues (e.g. The Rolling Stones).

Term.Name: Rhythm and Blues
Term.Definition: 1960s RandB (eg. The Rolling Stones) not 1990s RandB (eg. Teddy Riley).

Term.Name: Dancehall
Term.Definition: Also known as Ragga or Bashment

Term.Name: World/Traditional/Ethnic/Folk music
Term.Definition: Music that is the product of a tradition that has been evolved through the process of oral transmission

Term.Name: Personal finance
Term.Definition: Advice and information for individual consumers concerning financial products and services.

Term.Name: Computer Games
Term.Definition: Programme about games played on a computer

Term.Name: Do-it-yourself
Term.Definition: Where the consumer is given advice on how to perform home improvements themselves

Term.Name: Music
Term.Definition: teaching how to play musical imstruments on learning how to appreciate music

Term.Name: Board Games
Term.Definition: Monopoly, Scrabble, Mah-jong, Draughts (checkers), Backgammon etc

Term.Name: Gaming
Term.Definition: Non-card games such as roulette, craps, etc

Term.Name: Shopping
Term.Definition: Consumer shopping advice: Not a programme designed to sell a specific product to the consumer

Term.Name: Aviation
Term.Definition: Programme consisting of elements on aviation as a hobby, eg private pilots and general aviation. Elements concerning commercial avaiaton should be categoriesed in Air Transport (3.1.8.1) and elements concerning Aviation as a sport should be in 3.2.14 and its sub-categories
